All,

Just read this:
http://www.ftc.gov/opa/2003/10/cpreport.htm

It is re=
lated to the recent US Patent discussion.  The FTC recommendation seems lik=
e a move in the right direction, although I think it is still not enough.

=

Jim O'Flaherty, Jr.


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Derek James =

  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, October 30, 2003 9:57 AM
  S=
ubject: Re: [neat] Re: NeuroBlast


  --- Colin Green <cgreen@...=
> wrote:
  > :) I haven't had chance to do the thorough P.I. job
  > you se=
em to be doing 
  > Derek but from what you've said it all sounds a bit
  >=
 odd. 

  I guess I didn't do *that* thorough a job...I didn't
  find his p=
apers. :)

  > Exactly how can 
  > someone patent Hebbian learning anyway?=
 Aren't
  > patents  supposed to 
  > contain/define something that is uniq=
ue and distinct
  > from what has been 
  > done before. 

  Well, they *sh=
ould* be, but I've heard quite a bit of
  cirticism of our patenting proced=
ures (e.g., the U.S.
  Patent Office has apparently issued patents for how =
to
  make toast and techniques for swinging on playground
  swings).

  > N=
othing wrong with a healthy dose of skepticism, it
  > is the basis of 
  >=
 scientific discovery after all. I suspect you may be
  > jumping the gun 
=
  > though, I'm sure he's a thouroughly nice chap.

  I don't know how *nic=
e* he is, but maybe you're right.
  At least there are some references for =
his
  credentials.  He does use very broad, grandiose
  rhetoric regarding =
neural networks (e.g., he calls
  neural networks "brains", "The brains wil=
l be trained
  to solve a famous engineering problem: balancing an
  invert=
ed pendulum.").  I suppose he does so in order
  to try to impress prospect=
ive investors.

  Fair enough.  

  Derek
